abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Low Carbon Development
            Policy Loan (DPL) Project for Mexico were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            low or negligible, Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: the Government of Mexico was fully committed to
            developing its climate change strategy of which this DPL is
            an important part. The DPL drew on the extensive analytical
            work done on low-carbon development in Mexico, which was
            also used to prepare Mexico's clean technology fund
            investment plan, the energy efficiency and renewable energy
            assistance programs, and the sustainable urban transport
            program. The low-carbon DPL benefitted from the World
            Bank's ongoing dialogue and good relationship with
            Mexico on a range of climate change issues. This included
            previous cross-sectoral DPLs, and other operations in Mexico
            on both climate mitigation and adaptation. The DPL
            benefitted by placing coordination of the substantive
            aspects of the program with Ministry of Environment and
            Natural Resources (Secretaria de Medio Ambiente y Recursos
            Naturales) (SEMARNAT) which has an overall understanding of
            Mexico's broad climate change program. SEMARNAT played
            an important coordinating role taking responsibility not
            only for those environment and resources aspects within in
            domain (such as forestry), but assuming responsibility for
            the broader global environmental goals of the DPL. This
            project found that it was difficult to define meaningful
            targets that can be achieved in only 18 months. As a partial
            solution, and given the lack of mid-year data for many of
            the indicators, the time period for measuring the targets
            was extended to 24 months.
